title: How were children depicted in the early 20th century? - Quora

response.answer_text: I remember in the late 1950s, that when we went to Grandma’s for a visit that included dinner with other friends beyond just members of the family, that the children were given a separate table, usually in the kitchen. My grandparents were considered “upper crust” in the small Southern Oregon town they lived in. The living-room also, was “off-limits” unless accompanied by an adult, and if there was to be a piano gathering with drinks and some music, we were sent to bed upstairs. Generally speaking in a holdover from the 19th Century affectation that “children are to be seen, but not heard” we were also constantly admonished to keep our voices down and play outdoors in the back yard only. One of the things that at twelve, drew me to my Grandma’s husband, was that on occasion, he would ask my opinion of a subject. Sometimes, music, sometimes a current event, but that always took place when it was just the two of us, as if engaging a child in intellectual discussion was also “off limits”. I remember how stiff and formal portraiture of children was, from the colonial times until the early twentieth century. It felt as if adults really did not know how to think about children unless as small adults.
